intro: Froelichia scoparia, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and succulent-like leaves. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowering period occurs in the spring and summer, producing vibrant pink or red blooms. Froelichia scoparia is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators.
